context: Ryan explains the boundary between air carrier software and type certification software to a colleague, translating regulatory concepts into an accessible mental model while maintaining psychological safety.

text.msg: I spoke to Phil and I think it's slide 11... I'm talking very specifically about the software that's going to be used for the FAA TC testing...
Ahhh... so if the function sits inside the TC/part 25 boundary, then it will be owned by the MVSS or the vehicle teams...
No idea what Part 25 is lol we should probably talk :)
I'm an airspace person lol please don't make fun of me.
Not at all! there is a terrible learning curve/cliff to overcome at this job and I'm def here to help :)
Basically, there are planning functions that a dispatcher or operations person will do far in advance (business case)... and planning that a pilot will do before they take off (safety case)...
if you're talking about a function that falls in the first bucket, that's the FOS/air carrier... if it's the second bucket, that's type cert...

internal.thought: I want to anchor the answer around ownership boundaries rather than implementation details, because that's the real source of confusion.
I explicitly normalize the learning curve to keep the conversation safe and productive.
I switch to a business-case vs safety-case framing because it's the fastest way to transfer intuition across domains.
